reversi

Class Game

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Thread
      • reversi.Game
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable, GameController

    public class Game
extends java.lang.Thread
implements GameController
    The controller which takes care of the correct flow of the game.

    The life cycle of the player algorithms

    1. Game creates two algorithm objects using their parameterless (default) constructors
    2. After this, both algorithms will be called until the game ends.
      1. Game calls the init() method of the algorithm. The method call is done from a parallel thread to make sure that no computation is done at this time.
      2. Game starts the actual algorithm by creating a new thread which calls the run() method of the algorithm. In the run() method the algorithm performs the actual computation based on the initial values given in init() call.
      3. When the time is up, the computation thread is stopped unless a move has been issued before that. At the same time, the requestMove() method of the algorithm is called to inform the algorithm that it is time to make the move. The algorithm must respond to the requestMove() call with the doMove() call no later than 300 ms after the requestMove() call.
    3. Game calls the cleanup() method of both the algorithms
    When the time is up, Game ends the execution of the algorithm, no matter which state the algorithm is in. If the algorithm does not make a move in time or it makes an illegal move, it is disqualified.

    If the algorithm can not make any move, it must inform the controller with the doMove(null) call. This gives the turn to the other algorithm. For example:

     if (state.getPossibleMoveCount(myIndex) == 0)
   controller.doMove(null);

    • Method Detail

      • doMove

        public void doMove(Move move)
        Tells the game controller the move the algorithm has chosen. When the algorithm is finished with computation or it is out of time, it must send the chosen move to the controller. An example of a method in the Jarvis class: 
         public class MyAlgorighm implements ReversiAlgorithm
 {
   ...

   public void requestMove(Game requester)
   {
     requester.doMove(new Move(selectedX,selectedY,myIndex));
   }

   ...
 }
        Note that the algorithm does not need to wait for the requestMove() call if it finishes the computation before the call.
        Specified by:
        doMove in interface GameController
        Parameters:
        move - The chosen move. The coordinates define where to place the disc and the index is used to check that the right player is making the move.

      • getLastMove

        public Move getLastMove()
        Returns the last move made in the game.
        Returns:
        A Move object containing the last move or null, if the last player was not able to make a move.

      • getCurrentPlayer

        public int getCurrentPlayer()
        Returns the index of the player whose turn it is
